data.title: Include Configure Task Runner when Code is opened on a file
data.body:
Testing #4019 

When the workspace is opened on a file and not on a folder, then there is no `Configure Task Runner` action in the Command palette. While task.json is only supported when Code is opened on folder. It would be better to have the command in the palette and to show a message that this Command is only available when opened on a folder. 

I took me a while to figure out why I cannot configure a task when I opened a single file...

data.title: catch up with TS 1.8.9 and honour file size event
Generate 'isWatching' could be true if task has 'watch' in name

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Related to #4019

When generating a `tasks.json` we always set the `isWatching` to `false`, however we could use a simple heuristic to set this to `true` if a task name has 'watch' in the name. IMHO this heuristic could work nicely in practice.

To repro, just generate `tasks.json` for vscode repo

data.title: Generated tasks.json is incomplete - only has last 2 tasks from gulpfile
data.body:
Related to #4019
- VSCode Version: 18ebb4a4f5491af7b16e91e42fc36410bbb2e4d7
- OS Version: El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
1. vscode repo, delete `tasks.json`
2. Configure task runner > gulp
3. Notice the generated `tasks.json` only has `watch-extensions-build`and `test` task, while all the other tasks from the `gulpfile.js` are ignored

```
{
    // See http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "gulp",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": [
        "--no-color"
    ],
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "watch-extensions-build",
            "args": [],
            "isBuildCommand": true,
            "isWatching": false,
            "problemMatcher": [
                "$lessCompile",
                "$tsc",
                "$jshint"
            ]
        },
        {
            "taskName": "test",
            "args": [],
            "isTestCommand": true
        }
    ]
}
```

data.title: Bail early if --diff is not used with correct arguments of 2 existing files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. code --diff file1 file2 where file2 doesn't exist

Code opens with the second file empty in a dirty buffer. I can't see any use case for this. I think a better behavior would be to show a dialog that the second file doesn't exist.

data.title: Configuring a gulp task runner takes more than 3s sometimes
data.body:
Related to #4019
- VSCode Version: 18ebb4a4f5491af7b16e91e42fc36410bbb2e4d7
- OS Version: El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open vscode repo, delete `tasks.json`
2. Configure Tasks Runner > gulp
3. `tasks.json` is generated only after 3 seconds, I would expect it is instantanious

data.title: Allow to edit the left hand side of a diff editor if possible

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
You can hit it by using `Compare with` action and `--diff`. This is really sad. The editor on the left should only be read-only if the input behind it is really read-only (coming from the git index, for example).

cc @alexandrudima @bpasero

data.title: CentOS: Code Alpha doesn't show up in the Application Installer after installation
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: CentOS6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install rpm package using Application Installer
2. Switched to the installed tab

Observe: vscode is not listed. However it is installed successfully.

data.title: Editor title changes as soon as I edit a file, when using --diff
data.body:
Related to #3954
1. `code-alpha -d file1.txt file2.txt`
2. Edit `file2.txt`

The editor title will change to `file2.txt`.

data.title: 'Auto detecting the task system failed' can be more user friendly
data.body:
Related to #4019

Steps to Reproduce:
1. have a broken `gulpfile.js`
2. generate task runner > choose gulp
3. Notice the error
4. This should be a warning, not an error
5. There should be an action to open the output service, task channel to make it easier for the user to locate the error

![screen shot 2016-03-14 at 16 13 23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/13749028/edb554e6-e9ff-11e5-8393-e72e5cc6a121.png)

data.title: Column selection does not cover folded text
data.body:
testing #4092
OS: Linux
- fold some text
- select columns across the folded text
- expand the folded regions

Observe: no columns selected in expanded text

This behavior is different (inconsistent) from normal text selection mode.

data.title: Workspace settings info message wording
data.body:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/13748555/8ca4652c-e9fd-11e5-8942-75cdababa543.png)

To me it was not immediately clear what 'Never show again' refered to. Never show me the user settings editor again? Also I found 'Never' a bit harsh.

Maybe 'Don't show again' or 'Don't ask again' 
or "Always Ignore', 'Ignore' (instead of 'Close')

The better solution would be if the User settings editor has a warning on the actual settings that are overwritten.

data.title: Toggle render whitespace has no impact on default keybindings
data.body:
- File > Preferences > Keyboard Shortcuts
- File > View > Toggle Render Whitespace

-> Note that this has no impact on the 'Default Keyboard Shortcuts'

data.title: Configuring tasks has more text than a Twilight novel
data.body:
Related to #4019

![screen shot 2016-03-14 at 15 48 33](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/13748263/58faa7dc-e9fc-11e5-9215-4452e6a16fc3.png)

Instead of repeating 'Creates a tasks.json file for' multiple times I suggest to do the following:
- Rename 'Pick a tasks template' to 'Create a 'tasks.json' file for'
- Cut all the descriptions in half by removing the 'Creates a tasks.json file for' part
  - e.g Creates a task.json file that compiles using msbuild -> compiles using msbuild

data.title: [folding] Some useful editor actions (like fold/unfold) are not available for readonly files
data.body:
- debug a node app a stop somewhere
- in the CALL STACK select a frame from an internal module
- in the editor fold a method
  Observe: this works fine
- press F1 and type "fold"
  Observe: the fold and unfold actions are not available

data.title: Provide a setting to define the `locale`
data.body:
I can configure the locale on the command line using --locale. The issue is that the setting can easily be lost since Code launches Code again without this command line setting, e.g., after an auto update or after installing an extension.

In addition, a setting is more user friendly than a command line switch.

data.title: Command line tool installation wants 'code' alias removed, no such alias present.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.10
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.3

On attempting to install 'code' command line, I get the following: 
  'Please remove the 'code' alias from '/Users/kstevens/.bashrc' before continuing.'

'alias' returns the following: 

alias acsdev='ssh -l kcs6 acsdev.acsu.buffalo.edu'
alias cmsdev='ssh -l kcs6 cms-dev.acsu.buffalo.edu'
alias cq_start='cd /Applications/day/5.6.1-custom-v2/crx-quickstart/bin/ && ./start && cd -'
alias gcam='git commit -am'
alias ls='ls -la'
alias rvm-restart='rvm_reload_flag=1 source '\''/Users/kstevens/.rvm/scripts/rvm'\'''
alias sandbox='cd ~/code/src/ubcode/sandbox/kcs6'
alias simple_server='python -m SimpleHTTPServer 9000'
alias tree='tree'
alias ubcms='cd ~/code/src/ubcode/ubcms_local/'
alias ubcode='cd ~/code/src/ubcode'
alias vlt='/Users/kstevens/bin/vault-cli-2.4.34/bin/vlt'

[example_bashrc.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/172170/example_bashrc.txt)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Not sure, it might be machine specific.  
2. I have included my .bashrc file. I have tried commenting out any line with 'code' in it, in case a poorly formed regex was to blame. No joy.

data.title: Mac: Recent files should be split into files and folders
data.body:
I love `-w`, am using it left and right. The problem is that all those files are occupying space in my **Recent** list... My most common workspaces don't even show up anymore after a few simple file edits.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/13747951/f994e59c-e9fa-11e5-9530-866fd9793403.png)

Could we provide two groups of recent? Files and folders, separately?

data.title: Column select mode spans rectangle in unexpected way
data.body:
testing #4092

OS: Linux

I would expect that "Shift+Alt+mouse drag" spans a rectangle between the mouse down and the mouse up location. But this is not what I observe. Instead the rectangle spans from the previous caret location to the mouse up location. This is unexpected and less useful.

(in Sublime Alt-Cmd spans a rectangle between the mouse down and the mouse up location).

data.title: Extension errors should be aggregated
data.body:
Related to #4024

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install an extension, create errors in it's `package.json`
2. Click on the extensions widget in the status bar, notice you get multiple error notifications
3. It would be cool if all the error notifications are aggreagted per extension, that way the user would not get scared with a bunch of errors in his face

![screen shot 2016-03-14 at 15 29 05](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/13747689/c0107dd2-e9f9-11e5-87ed-1372be934810.png)

data.title: Maybe `-w` should not spawn Code as a child, when it is not running yet
data.body:
Related to #4006 

OS X

This is more of a discussion item mixed with a few issues. This also **only** applies to when Code is not already running.

There are many repercussions to spawning Code as a direct child of the cli code and we should maybe stay away from it and always spawn as an independent process.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/13747501/ce582760-e9f8-11e5-84fa-cf796edd3b09.png)

Here are a few examples why:
#### Move to background
1. Launch `code-alpha -w`
2. Hit <kbd>Ctrl Z</kbd> in the Terminal, which will send that process to the background
3. Switch to Code's window, it will appear frozen, you can't do anything, spinny comes along
4. Go back to terminal, run `fg` to bring Code back to life
#### `SIGINT`
1. Launch `code-alpha -w`
2. Type a few characters to get a dirty buffer
3. Switch back to the Terminal, hit <kbd>Ctrl C</kbd>
4. Switch back to Code and hit `Cancel` when it asks you about the dirty files
5. You immediately get an error from the shared process. What happened was that that `SIGINT` caused by <kbd>Ctrl C</kbd> propagated to all our process structure and killed most, except the renderer and its children. After the `Cancel`, the renderer and children became orphan processes.

Check whether using `detached: true` makes sense.
